response.answer_text: MONEY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Rather the lack of money! Massive strikes on the home front in Russia, food rationing that drove the cost of food to exuberantly high prices, a growing discontented populous. When orders were given to fire on the riotous populous, soldiers disobeyed orders and shot their officers instead. The February Revolution had started, and quickly spread through the ranks. For Russia, the soviets began to consolidate power, and a new Communist regime assumed total control of the Russian Government. The Communists under Lenin signed a disastrous peace deal with Germany, in order to fight a raging civil war to stay in power. The lack of money caused by one of America’s wealthiest Bankers, Jacob Schiff, because of the Tsar’s ill treatment of the Jews, led to the Russian Army collapsing and rebelling, leading to the downfall of the Tsar.

Your question: Why did Russia do so bad in World War 1? 1st: The Tsarist monarchy made people generals and cabinet ministers based on their loyalty and their relationship with the Tsar and Tsarina, rather than competence. In war, this produced large casualty counts and hundreds of thousands of personal tragedies for Russian families. That is not a situation that builds loyalty to the government or desire to continue to prosecute a war. Despite the observation above, the Russian army was actually tactically superior to the Austro-Hungarian army, but tactically and operationally inferior to the German army. Under General Brusilov (Google him! World War I: The Brusilov Offensive 1916) they were trained to be tactically very close to the Germans, almost operationally equal to the Germans. But there was only one Brusilov. 2nd: Russia was an industrializing country, not an industrial one like Germany. This put Russia at a disadvantage in producing weapons, ammunition, and in transportation. 3rd: The Russian strategic concept, like the French and German concepts at the beginning of the war, was a short war. But they got a long war, which meant that the peasants they recalled from the reserves to fill out their army were not in the fields harvesting and planting. So they ran short on food. And combined with point 2 above, they were not able to move enough food to the cities. This produced great discontent in the cities, a situation favorable to revolution. 4th: The Germans transported Lenin from Switzerland to a place where he could get into Russia. This lit the fuze on revolution.

My paternal grandfather, a saber-wielding Cossack on horseback, was machine-gunned by the Germans. He somehow survived (IIRC) nine bullets, decided that he no longer wanted to be part of the Tsar’s vanguard, defected and immigrated illegally to the US. Somehow, despite having absolute power in a country with vast resources, the monarchy managed to be invested in all the wrong things. That smacks of corruption and it echoes the pattern of collapse of the USSR’s state capitalism seventy years later.

Horrible military leadership, insufficient logistics particularly given its size and the amount of troops that needed to be moved and supplied, technology for said massive force versus their opponents in Europe, and internal disunity. A palace coup happened followed by two revolutions. All in 1917 right before the Western front offensive and amphibious landing operation in Istanbul.  In 1918 German&Österreich spies - turned Bolsheviks government signed separate peace treaty with Central powers (just like Romanian German-controlled government in 1918). Allies were more than happy - no need to share the spoils of war. That's all.
They didn't loose really. They had a revolution in the middle of the war that when in power took them out of the war.

Yes, in December 1917 the Bolshevik government signed an armistice with Germany and Austria-Hungary and then negotiated what concessions they would make in the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk in March 1918. However, once the Kaiser abdicated and the Germans signed their own armistice with the remaining allied powers in November of 1918, the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk became null and void. Not that it mattered as Russia was convulsing under full scale Civil War at the time which would last until 1922.

The Russians signed the Treaty of Brest-Lutsk which, essentially, signed away the Baltic States, Finland, and a good part of both Ukraine and Poland. Trotsky/Lenin were only saved from this folly by the Allies who defeated Germany and wanted to punish Germany more than Revolutionary Russia.

For many reasons. The Romanov’s refusal to modernize from an absolutist autocratic monarchy, underfunded and under equipped soldiers at the wars outbreak, many officers and generals in place due to their title or relationship with the Czar and not from merits, the rebellions and revolutions in previous recent decades left a society ready for change and ready to die for it. One could write many books on why Russia was Unsuccessful during the first world war. Many of these political reasons feed directly into the military reasons, by all counts the Russian soldier was brave and capable, but wasted by his commanders. Place a military and government with such dysfunction as this against a largely homogeneous, militaristic and enthusiastic German Empire and its not terribly hard to see why such field failures took place. However, later into the war the Russians were very capable, with fast amounts of Artillery and of course their legendary manpower reserves. Many aspects of the Russian military became incredibly competent. Not so long after is when the political issues began to unravel the threads holding Russia together, this newfound military competency would then be turned on themselves and lead into the Russian Civil war which would result in the emergence of the Soviet Union.
